edu.uiuc.ncsa.security.core.cache

Class Cleanup<K,V>

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Thread
      • edu.uiuc.ncsa.security.core.cache.Cleanup<K,V>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Runnable

    public class Cleanup<K,V>
extends Thread
    General utility for applying retention policies to maps (which covers all caching as well as stores). This may be used either directly by calling age() or by running this as a thread.

    Use

    Create an instance of this either
    • as <Identifiable, CachedObject> for caches
    • as <key, value> for a map or store.
    You must then set some RetentionPolicy so that the cleanup knows when to expunge entries (there are several possible policies and you can have as many as you want, though it is up to you to ensure your policies make sense.) Start this in its own thread and it will quietly clean up ever so often. To stop the thread, call the setStopThread(boolean) to true and the thread will halt as soon as it wakes up. YOu can also kill the thread directly but generally that can do bad things if the thread is in the middle of, say, updating you store. Most web servers will wait until all threads exit of their own accord before finishing a shutdown, incidentally.

    Created by Jeff Gaynor
    on 7/12/11 at 11:39 AM

      • setStopThread

        public void setStopThread(boolean stopThread)
        Sets the flag to stop this thread. The next time the thread wakes up after this is enabled, the thread will exit. This allows for a clean shutdown of caching.
        Parameters:
        stopThread -
